newsitem.title: ITALY: Italian court upholds sentences in graft trial.
newsitem.headline: Italian court upholds sentences in graft trial.

text.p: An Italian appeals court upheld sentences against top politicians on Saturday, including former prime minister Aldo Forlani in what has become known as "the mother of all corruption trials".

The Milan court took six days to arrive at its decision in a case that originally lasted 16 months when it was spearheaded by former anti-graft magistrate Antonio Di Pietro and televised across Italy.
The trial will now pass to the Cassation Court, the final stage in Italian justice.

The court upheld convictions for illegal party financing against both Forlani, a former Christian Democrat who faces a prison term of 28 months, and Northern League leader Umberto Bossi. Neither man was in court on Saturday.
The fiery secessionist was found guilty of accepting some 200 million lire ($118,000) in bribes for use by the League in their 1992 electoral campaign.

Also upheld were a three years' jail sentence for former Christian Democrat minister Severino Citaristi and six months for Republican Party leader Giorgio La Malfa. Both were sentenced for illegal party financing.
The Enimont trial involved the chemical company Montedison, which paid more than $100 million in kickbacks to extricate itself from a disastrous joint venture with state energy company ENI.
The court accepted plea-bargain requests from four former Montedison managers while former Milan mayor Paolo Pillitteri was cleared of all charges.
"I heard about my acquittal from television -- my wife turned it on and what great news it was," said Pillitteri, the brother-in-law of former prime minister Bettino Craxi.
Craxi, who has had several convictions for corruption and who lives in self-imposed exile in Tunisia, was also sentenced, but his appeal will be considered separately by the court on July 2.
